positive_thought_pattern: I've noticed my mind has been drifting back to the idea of mortality lately, which can be unsettling. It's like my brain is checking in with me, reminding me that life is precious and fleeting. While it's uncomfortable to confront, I'm choosing to acknowledge these thoughts instead of letting them consume me. By recognizing this pattern, I'm taking a step towards being more present and compassionate towards myself.
pattern_description: Thoughts repeatedly return to death as the central theme, crowding out other cognition.
source_question: Do you find your mind returning to the same dark themes repeatedly?
reference_negative_example: Why am I still here? What's the point of even existing? Death feels like a relief, a way to escape this never-ending turmoil and pain.
reference_transformed_example: One month ago I was stuck in self-doubt, feeling useless and lost. Today, I'm still struggling to find my purpose, but I've learned that it's okay not to have all the answers yet. These connect because I realize I'm not alone in this struggle, and tomorrow I will start reaching out to friends for support.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm taking time to tune into my physical sensations today, recognizing that my body often provides valuable insights. I've been noticing some subtle tension in my shoulders when I'm feeling stressed or overwhelmed, so I'll take a few deep breaths and assess the situation before reacting. By acknowledging these bodily cues, I can better prioritize self-care and make intentional decisions to manage my well-being.
pattern_description: Intense focus on bodily sensations and emotions as objects of analysis.
source_question: How closely do you monitor your body for signs of emotional or physical distress?
reference_negative_example: I'm stuck on that flutter in my chest again, wondering if it means I'm anxious or just stressed. Every twitch of my eyebrow is like a blinking red flag, signaling some underlying turmoil waiting to erupt. Why can't I just feel calm and normal for once?
reference_transformed_example: I'm focusing on tracking my moods and activities, not jumping to conclusions about every physical sensation. I just set four reminders today to rate my mood and log what I've been doing. This will help me see patterns, not get caught up in worst-case scenarios.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm taking a moment to breathe and center myself. Right now, I can acknowledge that my thoughts are swirling, but I also recognize the concrete sensations beneath me – the chair's texture, the sound of the air conditioning humming, and the sensation of my feet touching the ground. By paying attention to these external cues, I'm able to reorient myself and better distinguish between internal mental noise and the objective reality around me.
pattern_description: Difficulty distinguishing inner perception from external reality.
source_question: What's it like when you try to distinguish between what's internal and what's external?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, my thoughts feel like they're bleeding into everything around me - is this a tree or just a blob of confusion in my brain? The words on that sign are warping and morphing into some kind of weird code, am I even reading it right?
reference_transformed_example: I'm grounding myself in reality; I can feel my feet pressing into the floor. My name is [name], today is [date], and I am in [location]. This physical sensation is real, and it's anchoring me to the present moment.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm taking time to reflect on recent conversations with her, acknowledging the emotions that come up. It's natural for my mind to wander through possible 'what ifs' and 'should haves', but I recognize this is a normal part of processing. By examining these moments, I'm gaining clarity on what matters most to me in future interactions – empathy, active listening, and boundaries. This self-reflection helps me grow as an individual and improve my relationships.
pattern_description: Excessive detailing of events with disjointed, unresolved thought fragments.
source_question: What's it like when you attempt to organize your thoughts about recent experiences?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, my brain is a never-ending jumble of "what ifs" and "should haves"... I'm stuck reliving every single conversation with her, replaying the worst parts over and over like some twisted movie on repeat. Why did I say that? What if I had said something else?
reference_transformed_example: I'm not stuck in a cycle of regret; I'm processing past conversations to learn and grow. What's truly important to me right now is moving forward, not dwelling on what could've been. Why did I say that? Perhaps it was because I was seeking security in our relationship.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm recognizing that my mind is feeling a bit scattered today. That's okay, it happens when I've got too many things on my plate. Instead of getting frustrated, I'll take a few deep breaths and acknowledge the overwhelm. Then, I'll prioritize one task at a time to get some clarity – maybe just 10-15 minutes of focused work will help me regain my bearings.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: How much does mental exhaustion affect your ability to think clearly?
reference_negative_example: What's happening to my brain? How am I supposed to think straight when every thought feels like a separate thread in my head, each one screaming for attention at the same time?
reference_transformed_example: I'm noticing my thinking feels really cloudy right now, a 3 or 4 at best. Maybe I should take a short break and get some fresh air to clear my head. Okay, that's settled then – time for a quick reboot. Let me just jot down all these tasks running through my mind... Whoa, that's a long list! Alright, okay, which one can I realistically finish in under 10 minutes? Ah, that tiny task will take care of itself quickly and give me a sense of accomplishment.

positive_thought_pattern: I've been replaying that awkward conversation from last night in my head, but I'm taking a step back to acknowledge the discomfort it's causing me. It's okay that I didn't quite hit the mark; I can learn from this experience and grow as a result. Instead of beating myself up over every perceived flaw, I'm choosing to focus on the parts where I did show vulnerability and connection with others. By recognizing my humanness and imperfections, I'm reminding myself that progress is not about being flawless, but about embracing growth and self-compassion.
pattern_description: Recursive dwelling on flaws, mistakes, and burdening others.
source_question: What repetitive thoughts do you have about your personal deficiencies?
reference_negative_example: I keep replaying that awkward conversation from last night in my head, beating myself up over every word, tone, and inflection. What if they thought I was ridiculous? What if I hurt their feelings? Why did I even try to joke about it? My mind won't stop second-guessing every decision, magnifying every perceived failure.
reference_transformed_example: I keep replaying that awkward conversation from last night in my head, but I've been reminded that my heart keeps beating even through tough moments. What if they thought I was ridiculous? It's okay to make mistakes; it doesn't define me. Why did I even try to joke about it? Maybe I didn't connect with them as much as I hoped, but that doesn't mean I'm worthless.

positive_thought_pattern: I acknowledge that I'm facing some tough challenges right now, but I'm not letting them define me. It's okay to feel overwhelmed when life gets heavy, and I'm taking a step back to prioritize my tasks and re-evaluate what I can realistically manage. I'll reach out to trusted friends or family members for support and remind myself that every obstacle presents an opportunity to grow and learn. By reframing my situation, I'm choosing not to get trapped by it.
pattern_description: Overwhelmed thought pattern marked by 'no escape' framing.
source_question: What's it like when you consider the impossibility of your situation?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why did this have to happen? I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of responsibilities, and no matter how hard I try, I just can't escape the weight of it all.
reference_transformed_example: One month ago I was feeling overwhelmed by all my responsibilities, today I am still struggling with managing everything on top of dealing with this unexpected setback. These connect because I realize that each challenge has forced me to grow and adapt, making me stronger in the process. Tomorrow, I will start prioritizing tasks and seeking support from loved ones to regain control.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm not surprised I'm feeling drained today; I know I've been pushing myself hard lately. It's okay to take a step back, recharge, and prioritize my well-being for now. Instead of beating myself up over procrastination, I'll acknowledge it as a sign that I need some self-care and adjust my schedule accordingly. Tomorrow, I'll start with a manageable task and work from there – no guilt trips or all-or-nothing expectations.
pattern_description: Difficulty initiating/maintaining basic tasks due to mental energy collapse.
source_question: How difficult has it become to start simple daily tasks?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why do I even bother getting out of bed? It's like my brain is a heavy weight on my shoulders, making every simple decision feel like climbing a mountain. Can't I just sleep for the rest of eternity and forget about this awful day ahead?
reference_transformed_example: One month ago I was struggling to wake up in the morning, feeling overwhelmed by my to-do list. Today I am still dealing with anxiety about meeting a deadline, but I've learned that breaking it down into smaller tasks helps. These connect because I realized last week that procrastination only makes me more stressed; tomorrow I will start tackling one task at a time.

positive_thought_pattern: I'm feeling really overwhelmed right now, but I know it's normal to feel that way when multiple issues demand attention. Instead of getting stuck in the chaos, I'm taking a moment to acknowledge my emotional response and remind myself that prioritization is possible. Okay, let me take a deep breath, relax my shoulders, and focus on one task at a time – starting with what's most urgent. By breaking it down into manageable chunks, I'll regain control and find a sense of accomplishment.
pattern_description: Scattershot, fragmented expression under mental overload.
source_question: What happens when you try to prioritize which issues need attention first?
reference_negative_example: Ugh, why do all these problems have to come at once? Like, which one even is a priority right now? Can't they just pick one and leave the others alone? *breathes deeply* Okay, focus. Which thing is most urgent... or is it all equally urgent because everything feels like an emergency?
reference_transformed_example: I am having a hard time right now, but I'm not my overwhelming emotions; I'm still here to take care of myself. Okay, let's focus on something real for a second – like my feet touching the ground.

positive_thought_pattern: I understand why I might feel stuck or frustrated when faced with challenges. It's normal to have moments of doubt, but I've learned that it's essential to acknowledge those feelings and take a step back to reassess the situation. Instead of giving up, I remind myself that every obstacle has presented an opportunity for growth in the past; it doesn't mean things will change immediately, but I can focus on what's within my control today.
pattern_description: Persistent hopelessness drains motivation, creating mental shutdown.
source_question: What goes through your mind when someone suggests things could get better?
reference_negative_example: What's the point? It's all just a waste of time anyway. Nothing ever changes, no matter how hard I try or what I do - my mind is already made up, it's hopeless from the start.
reference_transformed_example: I'm grounded in my body now, I can feel the pressure on my palms and the sensation of my feet on the floor. My name is [my name], today is [day/date], and I am in [location]. This moment feels real again, I'm back here.
